shows.bio:
Other stage includes the Roundabout Theatre Company’s 2006 production of Joe Orton’s Entertaining Mr. Sloane, directed by Scott Ellis; Loot (Broadway,1986¬ Theatre World Award); Caryl Churchill's Serious Money (Broadway,1988); Prelude to a Kiss (Circle Rep, 1990 Obie Award); A Streetcar Named Desire (Broadway, 1992 Tony nomination), Macbeth (New York Shakespeare Festival 1998), The Twentieth Century (Roundabout, 2004), (Also, The Hartman in Stamford, Williamstown, Bay Street).

Baldwin has appeared in over fifty films, including Beetle Juice, Working Girl, Miami Blues, The Hunt for Red October, Glengarry Glen Ross, Malice, The Juror, The Edge, Ghosts of Mississippi, State and Main, The Cat in the Hat, The Cooler (National Board of Review Award for Best Supporting Actor, Oscar nomination), The Aviator, The Departed, It’s Complicated, Blue Jasmine, Still Alice, Mission Impossible: Rogue Nation, among many others.

On television Baldwin starred with Tina Fey on NBC’s 30 Rock, winner of the 2007, 2008 and 2009 Emmy for Outstanding Comedy Series. Baldwin has received seven SAG Awards, three Golden Globes, the Television Critics Award and two Emmy awards as Best Actor in a Comedy Series for his performance on the show. In 2011, Alec received his Star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. His company, El Dorado Pictures, has produced several projects including Nuremberg: Infamy on Trial for TNT television (Emmy nomination), The Confession for Showtime (WGA award for best adapted screenplay) and David Mamet’s film, State and Main.

Alec Baldwin is also a dedicated supporter of numerous causes related to public policy and the arts. He serves on the boards of People For The American Way, The Hamptons International Film Festival, The Roundabout Theatre and Guild Hall of East Hampton. He is an active supporter of The Radiation and Public Health Project, East Hampton Day Care Center, The Actors Fund, The Public Theatre/New York Shakespeare Festival, People for the Ethical treatment of Animals and The Water Keeper Alliance, among many others.

Baldwin’s book, A Promise to Ourselves (St. Martin’s Press) was published in paperback in the Fall of 2009. He is also the radio announcer for the New York Philharmonic. Baldwin has two daughters, Ireland Elliese and Carmen Gabriela and two sons, Rafael Thomas and Leonardo Angel. He is married to Hilaria Thomas Baldwin.
shows.job-title: Host, Here's The Thing; Mr. Glub the Goldfish, This Podcast Has Fleas
shows.lede: Alec Baldwin is a graduate of New York University (BFA, Tisch, ’94) and was presented with an Honorary Doctorate of Fine Arts from NYU in 2010. He last appeared on stage in 2015 in Arthur Miller's All My Sons at Guild Hall in East Hampton. In 2013, he starred in the Broadway revival of Lyle Kessler’s Orphans and in 2010, the Guild Hall (East Hampton) production of Peter Shaffer’s Equus directed by Tony Walton.
shows.name: Alec Baldwin

shows.title: Here's the Thing

about.body:
Award-winning actor Alec Baldwin gives the listener unique entrée into the lives of artists, policy makers and performers.

Alec sidesteps the predictable by taking listeners inside the dressing rooms, apartments, and offices of people such as comedian Chris Rock, political strategist Ed Rollins and Oscar winner Michael Douglas. Alec pursues great conversations in unexpected places to find out what motivates his guests, how they feel about what they do and what keeps them up at night. Here’s The Thing: Listen to what happens when a man you think you know surprises you.

Here's the Thing has its roots in public radio. In 2009, Alec joined with producers Lu Olkowski, Trey Kay, Kathie Russo, and Emily Botein to find fresh ways to engage in conversation on the radio. The group developed the idea of a new show that at its heart would look at what makes interesting people tick and create a platform for new and emerging ideas to be presented.

Here's the Thing: Listen to what happens when someone who's used to being the guest finds himself in chair of the host.

Read more about this project.

about.body:
Getting around New York is never easy, but summertime in the subways can be especially grim. So every Monday this summer, we’re highlighting some of the musicians who are making the commute a bit more pleasant.

We want to know about the musicians on your commute. Take a photo and post it on social media using #classicalcommute. Be sure to include the location of your photo.

series.title: Classical Commute
series.tease: Saluting some of the musicians who are making the commute a bit more pleasant.

shows.bio:
The Brian Lehrer Show was recognized with a 2007 George Foster Peabody Award for "Radio That Builds Community Rather Than Divides."

The New York Times called Lehrer a "master interviewer." Time magazine called the program "New York City's most thoughtful and informative talk show." The Daily News calls it "cutting edge" for its extreme interactivity and creative use of the internet. Political guests have ranged nationally from Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton to Mitch McConnell and Kellyanne Conway, and locally from Chris Christie to Cynthia Nixon and beyond. Cultural guests have included Wynton Marsalis, Margaret Atwood, Junot Diaz, Judd Apatow, Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, Yogi Berra, and so many others.

Lehrer is also a commentator on local and national issues on television and in print. He has appeared on TV channels including CNN, MSNBC, Fox Newschannel, C-SPAN, NY1, and The Colbert Report on Comedy Central. He has written op-ed pieces for publications including The New York Times, The Daily News, Newsday, and Slate. He also hosts a weekly television program on CUNY-TV, "Brian Talks New York.”

In addition to the Peabody, Lehrer has won numerous awards, including seven Associated Press New York Broadcasters "Best Interview" Awards since 2000 and “Best Talk Show” by the Garden State Journalists Association in 2009 and 2011.

Lehrer has been a questioner in televised New York City Mayoral Debates for every election since 1997.

He has hosted his eponymous program, originally called On The Line, since its inception in 1989. Prior, he was an anchor and reporter for the NBC Radio Networks, and an award-winning author and documentary producer.

Lehrer holds master's degrees in public health from Columbia University and journalism from The Ohio State University and a bachelor's in music and mass communications from the State University of New York at Albany.
shows.lede: Brian Lehrer is host of The Brian Lehrer Show, WNYC Radio's daily call-in program, covering politics and life, locally and globally. The show airs weekdays from 10am-noon on WNYC 93.9 FM, AM 820 and wnyc.org.
shows.name: Brian Lehrer

shows.title: Indivisible

about.body:
Indivisible is public radio's national show about America in a time of change. For the first 100 days of the new presidential administration, stations around the country are joining to bring you four nights a week of live, participatory conversation. Each night has its own host. Each night has its own theme. The common thread is your participation. All of the shows are call-ins. Comment anytime using #IndivisibleRadio. Subscribe to the podcast wherever you get your podcasts. The hosts include WNYC's Brian Lehrer, Minnesota Public Radio's Kerri Miller, WNYC's Kai Wright, John Prideaux and Anne McElvoy of The Economist and longtime conservative radio host Charlie Sykes. It's live radio. Anything can happen; don't miss it when it does.

Contact us: indivisibleradio@wnyc.org
RSS Feed

Find out if Indivisible is airing on your local station. 

All press inquiries and requests for interviews with “Indivisible” personalities and WNYC staff must be directed to press@wnyc.org.

shows.title: The Brian Lehrer Show

about.body:
Brian Lehrer leads the conversation about what matters most now in local and national politics, our own communities and our lives.

To comment on a particular conversation:

  • Find us on Facebook and Twitter
  • or call 212-433-WNYC (9692) to join on the air

Contact: blshow@wnyc.org.

attributes.title: This Wild Snow & Mozart
attributes.twitter-headline: This Crazy Shit Show of Snow Featuring Mozart

attributes.body:
It’s that time of year again — time for the Vienna Philharmonic’s annual New Year’s Concert featuring Strauss, Strauss and (you guessed it) more Strauss. Though Johann Jr. wasn’t the only waltz-writing Strauss (see Johann I, Josef and no-relation-Richard if you still haven’t gotten your Strauss fix from this), there’s a reason that Johann Strauss II is called “The Waltz King,” and that’s because he just wrote so many waltzes — hundreds, in fact. His most well-known in the genre is An der schönen, blauen Donau (On the Beautiful, Blue Danube), but we dug a little deeper into The Waltz King’s back catalogue to find more of his treasures. Here’s what we found:

Accelerationen (Accelerations Waltzes) 

There’s something dizzyingly beautiful about the way this waltz builds and builds upon itself. Strauss composed Accelerationen for the Engineering Students’ Ball at the Technical College of Vienna in 1860. It’s believed that Strauss began composing this set of waltzes on the back of a napkin, which just goes to show that inspiration can strike at any given moment.

Mephistos Höllenrufe (Mephisto’s Call From Hell)

Like Apple, when it comes to Strauss you can assume that “there’s a waltz for that,” including dancing with the devil. This was so popular at its 1851 premiere performance that it was repeated three times.   

Kuss Walzer (Kiss Waltzes)

How does Strauss say “I love you?” With a waltz, of course! He wrote the Kuss Walzer as a present for his second wife, Lili. Actually, Strauss wrote music for each of his wives: his first, Jetty, received Bluette-Polka Francaise (as well as Karnivalbotschafter on their honeymoon), and his third wife, Adele, got Adelen-Walzer.

Myrthenblüten (Myrtle Blossoms)

Also on the subject of love, this was written as a commission for the marriage of Crown Prince Rudolf of Austria and Princess Stephanie of Belgium, and was premiered at their wedding in 1881, originally with a chorus.

Rathausball-Tänze (Rathaus Ball Dances)

When you’ve written as many waltzes as The Waltz King, you might start to quote yourself (and others) to see which of your most hardcore fans are paying attention. Listen closely — does the beginning sound familiar? Composed for the first ball held in Vienna’s new Town Hall in 1890, Strauss based the beginning of this after the Blue Danube, and also quotes Haydn’s Gott erhalte Franz den Kaiser, which has been the anthem of both Germany and the Austrian Empire.

Freuet euch des Lebens (Enjoy Life!)

Composers have been quoting Strauss Jr. ever since The Waltz King assumed his throne — Gustav Mahler, in his Ninth Symphony, quoted Enjoy Life in the first movement. Given that symphony’s darkness and this waltz’s joy, one can only speculate as to what Mahler meant by referencing this dance.

Geschichten aus dem Wienerwald (Tales from the Vienna Woods)

Listen closely and you’ll notice an unusual instrument playing with the orchestra: a zither. This stringed instrument is featured prominently as a soloist throughout this waltz, lending it a folksy feeling.

Kaiser-Walzer (Emperor Waltzes)

This is one of Strauss’s most popular waltzes, composed to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the coronation of the Play this at your New Year’s party to waltz into 2019 like the monarch you are.

Seid umschlungen, Millionen! (Be Embraced, You Millions!)

Strauss took the title of this waltz from Schiller’s Ode to Joy (the same one Beethoven set in his Ninth Symphony), and dedicated it to his friend, Johannes Brahms — which seems fitting, given Brahms had been hailed as the next Beethoven.

Schatz-Walzer (Treasure Waltzes)

Strauss also found success as an operetta composer, particularly with Die Fledermaus (The Bat) and Der Zigeunerbaron (The Gypsy Baron). The Schatz Walzer is based on several themes from the latter work.

Wein, Weib und Gesang (Wine, Women and Song)

One wouldn’t think Wagner and Brahms had similar tastes in music, but they at least agreed that Strauss had a talent for writing waltzes — and Wein, Weib und Gesang was a particular favorite of both composers. (For what it’s worth, Verdi was also a Strauss fan, too.)

Wiener Blut (Vienna Blood)

It feels fitting to round out this list with Wiener Blut, given that Strauss waltzes are the musical blood of Vienna. Strauss composed this piece shortly after his initial operetta successes, and later incorporated its themes into an operetta-pastiche of the same name. Alfred Hitchcock was also a fan of Wiener Blut, using it throughout his 1941 film, Suspicion. (Hitchcock was obviously a fan of The Waltz King — in 1934, he directed a movie about the Strauss family, fittingly named Strauss’ Great Waltz.)
attributes.tease: With the annual Vienna Philharmonic New Year's Concert upon us, we dig into the compositions Johann Strauss Jr.'s for 12 great waltzes NOT named "The Blue Danube."
attributes.title: 12 Waltzes By Johann Strauss Jr. Not Named "The Blue Danube"
attributes.twitter-headline: 12 Waltzes By Johann Strauss Jr. Not Named "The Blue Danube"

attributes.body:
The world of online comment boards is not ordinarily the place for creativity and civility — but that never stopped Larry Eisenberg.

The writer and biomedical electrical engineer, who died December 25 at age 99, was a prolific Internet commenter, especially on The New York Times website, where he left more than 13,000 comments over 10 years.

The numbers are even more remarkable because his comments were almost always written as limericks.

Apart from The New York Times, which wrote a loving obituary, Eisenberg also frequented the WQXR website, especially for our Saturday opera matinees. He had a deep fondness for bel canto and Mozart, bolstered by a clear knowledge of the repertoire.

In his honor, we wanted to share some favorites from the more than 80 limericks he left on our pages. We’ll miss you, Larry.

Rossini

Of Rossini I'm a huge fan
I listen whenever I can
The Barber, what's more,
I truly adore,
For bel canto, Rossini's my man.

Beethoven loved it, and I, too,
Adore this Opera anew,
A Rossini gem
And age cannot stem
This vivacious musical brew!

Mozart

The plot each listener annoys
But the Music makes one rejoice,
Magic Flute on the whole
Is pure joy for the soul.
Operatically, a Rolls Royce!

Strauss II

The Fledermaus isn't my speed
A surfeit of schmaltz I can't heed,
'Til next week I'll wait
Queasiness will abate
A shot of real music I'll need.

Bizet

Of Bizet's Carmen, I ne'er tire,
The closing scene I most admire,
Musically a delight,
A Libretto that's tight,
Events that transpire are so dire!

Verdi

Verdi is my sine qua non,
Aida is a benison,
The Cast? Not the best,
But conducted with zest,
And the music is lovingly spun.

What a pleasure to hear Rigoletto!
The opening's so allegretto,
Verdi's melodies soar,
Love to hear it once more,
Will do so and without regret-o!

Gounod

Gounod's Faust? A tonal delight!
A good cast is doing it right!
The fate of Marguerite
Makes it all bitter sweet,
The message, alas, isn't trite.

Donizetti

A fine performance, it appeared,
Donizetti, I think, would have cheered,
Mad scene, by all odds,
Was fit for the gods,
Even Zeus himself would have teared.

I would forego meatballs & spaghetti
Just to listen to G. Donizetti,
Damrau, Juan Diego,
Portend a grand show,
Lighter, more airy than confetti!
attributes.tease: The world of online comment boards is not ordinarily the place for creativity and civility — but that never stopped Larry Eisenberg.
attributes.title: Remembering Larry Eisenberg, Lover of Limericks and Opera
attributes.twitter-headline: Remembering Larry Eisenberg, Lover of Limericks and Opera

shows.bio:
Newspapers: Philadelphia Inquirer classical music critic (2000 to the present) and USA Today music and theater critic (1983-2000).

Radio: WRTI-FM, contributor to Creatively Speaking with Jim Cotter (2009 to the present) and NPR Morning Edition, music commentator (1986-1989). 

Magazines: Frequent contributions to Gramophone and Opera News.

Film: Screenwriter for two Lawrence Kraman documentaries, David Amram The First 80 Years (to be premiered in November) and The Face on the Barroom Floor (to be completed 2013).

Education: MA in musicology from New York University, BS in journalism from Southern Illinois University. Born in Sycamore, Illinois. Now living in Philadelphia.
shows.lede: David Patrick Stearns is the classical music critic for the Philadelphia Inquirer, a contributor to WRTI-FM in Philadelphia and a frequent contributor to Gramophone and Opera News magazine.

attributes.body:
January must have been considered a lost cause in the history of New York concert going— until somebody realized it was a time to present music that's extremely meaningful to a certain constituency.

Bad weather and post-holiday exhaustion is likely to be irrelevant when it comes to the Prototype Festival and Green Mountain Project. Those who love extremely old and extremely new music — often the same people — will be out every night to take in what does not happen the rest of the year. Some of the larger institutions in town also present unusual artists and repertoire. And for those who just need to chill, there's a bit of that as well. 

Prototype Festival

With eight productions of cutting-edge operas and four additional events Jan 5–13 in venues around New York City, the festival is so large it's hard to pick and choose. And you can't expect the website's blurbs to describe pieces that are so hard to imagine. Having seen the London premiere of 4:48 Psychosis, Philip Venables' operatic adaptation of the final, suicidal work by the great playwright Sarah Kane (1971–99) about wrestling with crippling depression, I can say it's one of the most penetrating and dramatically resourceful operas to come out of Great Britain in recent years. But the experience is so singular that saying anything more specific would require a half hour. So go, unless you're having your own depressive episode (Jan 5, 6, 8, 9, 11 and 12 at Baruch Performing Arts Center). 

Composer Andrea Clearfield may be a new name to many New Yorkers, but she's been a solid Philadelphia presence for decades. She presents a Tibetan-influence work in-progress, Mila, Great Sorcerer, whose journey is from mass murder to enlightenment. (Jan. 11 and 12 at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater at John Jay College.) Much buzz is circulating around composer Ellen Reid, whose opera p r i s m concerns a child forced into a cloistered life by an unnamed disease (Jan. 6, 7, 9–12 at La MaMa Ellen Stewart Theatre). The festival also intersects with the Trinity Wall Street Evening Concert Series at St. Paul’s Chapel, which co-presents a Jan. 8 concert, performed by NOVUS NY under Julian Wachner, featuring possibly major premieres by Reid and David T. Little.

Under the Radar Festival

The Public Theater’s Under the Radar Festival is mostly theater, but Chambre Noire (Jan. 10–13) is something that could well intersect with the Prototype Festival: It’s a French / Norwegian production by a group called Plexus Polaire that takes place at the deathbed of Valerie Solanas — yes, the woman who shot Andy Warhol and wrote the notorious SCUM Manifesto, a radical futuristic vision of a world without men. Much of the story is told with puppets, video, music by Guro Skumsnes Moe and percussion by Ane Marthe Sørlien Holen. Let your imagination run and double it.

Cantata Profana

The hugely ambitious Visions of Silence program juxtaposes baroque composers you've barely heard of (Merula) with better-known (and rather fierce) moderns. Galina Ustvolskaya's Symphony No. 5 has its local premiere, though Salvatore Sciarrino's Ecstasy in One Act is the main piece on the program. (Jan. 18 and 19 at St. Peter’s Church Chelsea, 346 W. 20th.)

Green Mountain Project

All but unknown 50 years ago, the Monteverdi Vespers of 1610 is now considered one of the masterworks of Western civilization, and the Green Mountain Project — an extension of TENET's season — performs it annually despite its early 17th century requirements, from old instruments to arcane vocal techniques to church acoustics. Each year’s performances have perceptible advances in authority and understanding. This year's dates are Jan. 3 and 6, at Church of St. Jean Baptiste, Lexington Ave. at 76th.

More intriguing perhaps is “Behind Convent Walls” on Jan. 4, a program of music written by women composers of Monteverdi's time, often among cloistered communities, despite the Vatican's objections. It’s high quality music, and often reflecting the vocal personalities for which it was written. The program will be performed by Green Mountain Project in conjunction with TENET. On Jan. 5, Blue Heron and the Dark Horse Consort give a 16th-century program titled “Cantores y ministriles: Spanish Music in the Golden Age.” The pieces include Spanish polyphony as well as dance music, with a composer list headed by Cristobal de Morales. Both concerts are at Kirkland Chapel of Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 7 W. 55th St.

ARTEK

More Monteverdi, this time it's Madrigals Book VII that will be performed over two nights, Jan. 10 and 11 by ARTEK under Gwendolyn Toth at Corpus Christi Church, 529 W. 121st St. Rarely heard, these madrigals have extraordinary sophistication — and chart the composer's remarkable creative arc. As for the performers, ARTEK isn't the most consistent group out there. But when else do you hear this music live?

New York Philharmonic

The year starts with the perfect hangover concert: nothing too challenging, something perfectly melodic ... and that would be Dvořak’s Cello Concerto, played by the charismatic Gauthier Capuçon (Jan. 3–5). The end of the month (Jan. 24–26), though, brings one of the more eagerly awaited events in the new-music year: Julie Wolfe's Fire in my mouth, about the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory Fire of 1911 that killed more than 100 young immigrants. I never know why Wolfe likes to premiere pieces in an immersive environment — her music is perfectly powerful on its own — but true to form, there is video by Jeff Sugg. The vocal component is from The Crossing, the new-music chamber choir that can do anything.

Carnegie Hall

If a bit of normality is order by the middle of the month — and if there's one thing that would lure me away from the cutting edge — it's Spanish pianist Javier Perianes, who plays Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 27 with Orpheus Chamber Orchestra on Jan. 12. This is yet-another significant piano career that has been made by a Harmonia Mundi discography. As good as Perianes is at his native repertoire, he brings a fresh perspective where it's needed most — the established classics.

Metropolitan Opera

Last month's acclaimed revival of Otello with Gustavo Dudamel conducting Stuart Skelton and Sonya Yoncheva (in the role that made her name at the Met) continues Jan 2, 5 and 10. Then Pelléas and Mélisande returns Jan. 15, 19, 22, 25 and 31, with what could be a near-ideal cast: Paul Appleby, Isabel Leonard, Kyle Ketelsen, Ferruccio Furlanetto and Marie-Nicole Lemieux. Yannick Nézet-Séguin, who conducts all performances but the 31st, recently mused at a Juilliard School masterclass about how the opera might sound if sung in Quebeçois. Maybe next season? The month ends Jan. 30 with a Don Giovanni revival conducted by the brilliant Cornelius Meister, making his Met debut with Luca Pisaroni in the title role. 

New York Festival of Song

The catalog-like brain of Steven Blier has a Jan. 17 program at The Juilliard School centering on Kurt Weill's cabaret period in pre-Nazi Germany. Perhaps only Blier could unearth little-known Weill titles such as "Lottery Agent's Tango." Other music in this concert sung by emerging artists is by Friedrich Hollaender and Hanns Eisler.

Brooklyn Art Song Society

Ned Rorem used to be considered hopelessly conservative, though now he's the focal point of Brooklyn Art Song Society's “American Iconoclasts” series Jan. 4 at the Brooklyn Historical Society, 128 Pierrepont St., Brooklyn. And it's true that while seemingly every composer was bent on being modern, he just kept writing songs. This program includes two cycles, War Scenes and Poems of Love and the Rain, with singers including Dashon Barton, Sarah Brailey and others. 

Aprile Millo

New York City Opera is presenting Aprile Millo's first NYC appearance in nearly a decade, on Jan. 30 at Carnegie's Zankel Hall. She once dominated the Verdi wing of the Metropolitan Opera, but has been seldom heard in recent years, and it's hard to say why. In her infrequent, post-Met concerts, Millo still displayed the rich voice that the great Renata Tebaldi had compared to her own. Keep in mind, too, that Millo started young, so only now — at age 60 — is she approaching the typical retirement age for sopranos. So we'll see.
attributes.tease: There's a lot of great music happening around New York this January. Here's what to see.
attributes.title: Must-See Classical Concerts This January

attributes.body: On Christmas Eve, a holiday radio tradition returns — at 10 am we’ll present a broadcast of “A Festival of Nine Lessons and Carols,” live from the King’s College Chapel in Cambridge, England. Now in its 100th year, the 30-voice choir will transport all who tune in, interspersing seasonal music with biblical readings.

image-main.alt-text: King's College Choir for the 2017-18 academic year.
image-main.name: 1/kings-choir.jpg
image-main.caption: King's College Choir for the 2017-18 academic year.

attributes.tease: The legendary Christmas Eve service from Cambridge turns 100 this year.
attributes.title: Listen: ‘A Festival of Nine Lessons and Carols’
attributes.twitter-headline: Listen: ‘A Festival of Nine Lessons and Carols’

attributes.body:
This list gives a special shout out to some of the initiatives, organizations and people making an impact in the classical music world this year. Creatively bringing the arts into the lives of others, these projects and people hit a high note on our meter of joy. We hope reading about their work will leave you feeling like 2018 wasn’t so bad, after all. 

The Lullaby Project 

As the dedicated educational arm of Carnegie Hall, Weill Music Institute offers free programs and grants, as well as innovative ways of engaging New Yorkers in music making. Of these, the Lullaby Project stands out as particularly unique and meaningful, pairing “pregnant women and new mothers and fathers with professional artists to write and sing personal lullabies for their babies, supporting maternal health, aiding child development and strengthening the bond between parent and child.” The Lullaby Project works in homeless shelters, high schools and on Rikers Island. Check out this video and prepare to feel all warm and fuzzy — and then follow through on that sudden urge to call your mother. 

 

Composer Diversity Database

As a brand new resource, the Composer Diversity Database represents — pun intended — a progressive step towards a more inclusive canon. The search engine offers over three dozen filters to help users discover new music based on composers’ gender identity, ethnic or racial background, instrumentation, or all of the above. Search for people whose work you might have been missing, or contribute a new entry, here. 

Chineke! Foundation

Just three years old, Chineke! Foundation has taken the U.K. and Europe by storm as the first majority black and minority ethnic orchestra. This long-overdue organization is single-handedly tackling classical music’s diversity issues. By offering a flagship orchestra of seasoned professionals as well as a Junior Orchestra, Chineke! provides strong mentorship opportunities within its musician ranks. With supporters like Sir Simon Rattle, the Royal Philharmonic Society, and the BBC, the Chineke! Foundation is a testament to the experiences of its founder, the Nigerian-Irish double bassist Chi-chi Nwanoku.

 

Sphinx Organization 

Based in Detroit, Sphinx is the leader in pipeline programs that actively diversify the field of classical music. Empowering black and Latinx performers in various stages of their careers, Sphinx offers education programs for young people, audition support, ensembles like the Sphinx Virtuosi and, most recently, a development program for arts administrators pursuing leadership roles. The dedication and impact of this organization cannot be underestimated. Bravo! 

 

Public School Music Teachers Everywhere 

Whether you’re an active or recovering musician, it likely takes just seconds to remember the music teacher that changed your life. They sparked your passion for music, encouraged your creative drive or simply showed by example that there was a viable career path doing what you love. In schools across the country, we salute teachers who do the hard work of leading young people in making music. Want to feel particularly inspired about the state of music education? Check out the story of Bronx teacher Melissa Salguero, who won the Music Educator Award at the 2018 Grammys.

image-main.alt-text: The Catalyst Quartet, comprised of Sphinx Competition winners
image-main.name: 2018/12/catalystQ-1.jpg
image-main.caption: The Catalyst Quartet, comprised of Sphinx Competition winners

attributes.tease: With 2018 just about wrapped up, let's take a look back on some awesome initiatives and organizations that have made an incredible impact in the classical music world.
attributes.title: Beyond the Concert Hall: 5 Organizations Making a Difference in Classical Music in 2018
attributes.twitter-headline: Beyond the Concert Hall: 5 Organizations Making a Difference in Classical Music in 2018

shows.bio: James is a noted pineapple enthusiast and native of the original (read: Chesapeake) Bay Area. At the impressionable age of 17, he moved to New York in search of concrete pastures and scooped up a BA in history from Columbia University. Classical music had always been an interest, but it really switched on after he heard Yo-Yo Ma rip “Fear” from Astor Piazzolla’s Four Tango Sensations. It popped up on shuffle, and he listened to it no fewer than 40 times in a row.  He’s also game to talk about jazz, hip-hop, and wave (chill, synth, vapor, or otherwise). James is also fond of funky ales, fall foliage, all things nautical, and harsh winters. Some would say he has a passing interest in the post-romantic situational comedy Friends.
shows.lede: James Bennett II is a staff writer for WQXR.
shows.name: James Bennett, II

attributes.body: In November, mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato visited the Greene Space for an edition of “Classical Up Close,” WQXR’s event series profiling the projects and goings-on of classical musicians. The afternoon included an interview with Clemency Burton-Hill, in which DiDonato discussed singing at the Met and opera’s place in the contemporary world. She also talked about Camille Claudel: Into the Fire, Jake Heggie’s song cycle written for DiDonato, then sang excerpts alongside the Brentano String Quartet.

image-main.alt-text: Joyce DiDonato sings in The Greene Space
image-main.name: 2018/12/joycedd.jpg
image-main.caption: Joyce DiDonato sings in The Greene Space

attributes.tease: The opera singer joined Clemency Burton-Hill in the Greene Space to discuss her craft and share excerpts of a song cycle written just for her.
attributes.title: WQXR Best in Studio 2018: Joyce DiDonato and the Brentano String Quartet Perform a Personal Song Cycle
attributes.twitter-headline: WQXR Best in Studio 2018: Joyce DiDonato and the Brentano String Quartet Perform a Personal Song Cycle

attributes.body: When we geared up for Halloween this year in the best way we know how — a Beer Jam! Local brewery Kings County Brewers Collective (KBCB) came by to share some terrifyingly tasty brews, and a handful of musicians contributed some spooky tunes. Among them was harpist Bridget Kibbey, who amazed audiences as she played her own transcription of J. S. Bach’s Toccata and Fugue in D Minor, which has long been associated with all things creepy. The reason she took on this particular piece? “It was the product of a dare and a bet,” she explained. Clearly, she won handily.

image-main.alt-text: Harpist Bridget Kibbey plays Bach's 'Tocatta and Fugue in D minor.'
image-main.name: 2018/12/bk-harp.jpg
image-main.caption: Harpist Bridget Kibbey plays Bach's "Tocatta and Fugue in D minor.

attributes.tease: At a Halloween party in the Greene Space, harpist Bridget Kibbey put her own spin on Bach’s creepy classic.
attributes.title: WQXR Best in Studio 2018: Bridget Kibbey Brings Her Spookiest Bach
attributes.twitter-headline: WQXR Best in Studio 2018: Bridget Kibbey Brings Her Spookiest Bach

attributes.description: Ignite your love of classical music every day with the articles published in the WQXR blog. Here you can find blogs about classical music, playlist selections, curated videos, and other features highlighting the joy of great music.
